thread.title: Stocks end slightly higher; Starbucks adds Apple Pay; computer shipments continue to slide: Business News Links
thread.title_full: Stocks end slightly higher; Starbucks adds Apple Pay; computer shipments continue to slide: Business News Links | cleveland.com

author: Ray Jablonski, Northeast Ohio Media Group
title: Stocks end slightly higher; Starbucks adds Apple Pay; computer shipments continue to slide: Business News Links
text:
In this photo taken Friday, Oct. 17, 2014, Eddy Cue, Apple Senior Vice President of Internet Software and Services, demonstrates the new Apple Pay mobile payment system at a Whole Foods store in Cupertino, Calif. Starbucks has officially begin to accept Apple Pay at its locations. Eric Risberg, Associated Press Stock market news:
U.S. stocks closed slightly higher today, ending the S&P 500's best week for 2015 on a quiet note as investors waited for U.S. companies to report third-quarter earnings. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 33.74 points, or 0.2 percent, to 17,084.49, the S&P 500 gained 1.46 points to 2,014.89 and the Nasdaq Composite added 19.68 points to 4,830.47. ( Reuters )
World stock markets rose today on expectations the Federal Reserve will keep interest rates at a record low for at least several more months. ( Associated Press )
Oil prices peaked by the end of the week after rallying on rising geopolitical tensions and signs of slowing output had brought buyers back to the market. ( Financial Times )
Business news:
Starbucks is officially on board with Apple Pay, and will start allowing customers to pay for their beverages with just a tap of their iPhone or Apple Watch. ( San Jose Mercury News )
The House voted 261 to 159 today to lift restrictions on crude-oil exports, capping a year of heavy lobbying by the American Petroleum Institute, many of the nation's biggest petroleum companies and leading shale oil producers. ( Washington Post )
Walmart named Brett Biggs, an executive in its international division, as its next chief financial officer today. ( Associated Press )
SeaWorld Entertainment today said it would reconsider its proposed $100 million expansion of a holding facility for killer whales in California in the wake of new rules prohibiting the theme-park operator from breeding orcas. ( CBS MoneyWatch )
The Federal Reserve does not need to resort to negative interest rates or other policies to further ease monetary policy in order to lift excessively low inflation back to the central bank's 2-percent goal within a few years, a top Fed official said today. ( Reuters )
More than eight months after disclosing a major data breach, Uber is focusing on an IP address associated with the attack, which sources say is linked to the CTO of rival Lyft. ( PC Magazine )
Airlines already know how to pack 'em in, but in future they may be able to pile 'em high thanks to a blueprint for split-level seating invented by planemaker Airbus. ( Reuters )
Technology news:
Shipments of personal computers continued to slide during the third quarter, as the rise in the U.S. dollar made devices more expensive to purchase in other countries, say analyst reports from Gartner and IDC. ( USA Today )
Apple today rid its App Store of some applications it said could snoop on people's data and posed a security threat. ( AFP News )
Google said some of its services including Drive and Docs are facing disruptions. ( Reuters )
LogMeIn, which is looking to add more security capabilities to its remote computer access business, is buying password manager LastPass for $110 million in a deal officials with both companies praised but which raised concerns among some of LastPass' customers. ( eWeek )
